_prev_prog_3.Description:
Prevention Program

The ammonia refrigeration system at Purity Foods is considered a ?Program 3? level prevention program as described in Subpart D of 40 CFR 68 (68.65 through 68.87).  The requirements for the prevention program are equivalent to the provisions of 29 CFR 1910.119(a) through (p), OSHA?s Process Safety Management standard.  The following information details the prevention program elements and lists which personnel are assigned to implement the element:


2.2.1 Process Safety Information (40 CFR 68.65)

The Plant Engineer is responsible for maintaining information on the hazards of ammonia including health effects as well as physical and chemical data. Such responsibilities include the following:

a.  At a minimum, gathering and maintaining the following:
1.  For chemicals, an MSDS or other documentation containing the following information:
(a) Toxicity for the chemical
(b) Permissible exposure limits
(c) Physical data
(d) Reactivity
(e) Corrosivity
(f) Thermal and chemical stability
(g) Hazardous effects of inadvertent mixing of materials that could forseeably occur
(h) Other relevant information

The Plant Manager is responsible for maintaining process flow diagrams, process chemistry information, and operating ranges of process equipment.

a.  At a minimum, gathering and maintaining the following:
1.  For process technology, the following information:
(a) Block flow diagram or simplified process flow diagram
(b) Information on process chemistry
(c) Maximum intended inventory of the chemical
(d) Safe upper and lower limits for operating parameters such as temperature, pressure, flows or composition
(e) Evaluation of the consequences of deviation
(f) Other relevant information

2.  For equipment in the process, the following information:
(a) Materials of construction
(b) Piping and instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs)
(c) Electrical classification
(d) Relief system design and design basis
(e) Ventilation system design
(f) Design codes and standards employed
(g) Safety systems
(h) Material and energy balances for processes built after June 21, 1999
(I) Other relevant information

b.  Ensuring regular inspections and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration process equipment.


2.2.2 Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) (40 CFR 68.67)

The Safety Manager is responsible for assembling a team to evaluate the hazards of the process, documenting the results of the analysis, ensuring that the analysis is conducted at least every 5 years, and maintaining records of the analyses.  Responsibilities include the following:

a. At a minimum, determine and evaluate the hazards of the process using one or more of the following methods:
(1) What-If
(2) Checklist
(3) What-If/ Checklist
(4) Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP)
(5) Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA)
(6) Fault Tree Analysis, or
(7) An appropriate equivalent methodology

b.   Assure that the process hazard analysis addresses the following:
Hazards of the process
Identification of any previous incident which had a likely potential for catastrophic consequences
Engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards and their interrelationships, such as appropriate application of detection methods to provide early warning of releases
Consequences of failure of engineering and administrative controls
Stationary source siting
Human factors
Qualitative evaluation of a range of the possible safety and health effects of failure of controls

c.  Assure that the process hazard analysis is performed by a team with the following:
Expertise in engineering and process operations
At least one employee with experience and knowledge specific to the ammonia refrigeration system
One member knowledgeable in the specific process hazard analysis     methodology being used

d.  Establish a system to document the team?s findings by the following:
Assure that the recommendations are resolved in a timely manner
Document the resolution
Document actions to be taken
Complete actions as soon as possible
Develop a written schedule of when actions are to be completed
Communicate the actions to operating, maintenance, and other affected employees

e.  Update and revalidate the initial process hazard analysis at least every five (5) years

f. Retain process hazard analyses and updates or revalidations as well as documentation, for the life of the ammonia refrigeration system.


2.2.3Operating Procedures (40 CFR 68.69)

The Plant Manager is responsible for:
Developing and implementing written operating procedures for the ammonia refrigeration system, including steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations and safety systems and their functions
Making operating procedures readily accessible to employees who work in or maintain the ammonia refrigeration system
Reviewing operating procedures as often as necessary to assure that they reflect current operating practice, including changes in process chemicals, equipment and technology 
Annual certification that operating procedures are current and accurate
Developing and implementing safe work practices, such as:
lockout/tagout
confined space entry
opening process equipment or piping

2.2.4 Training (40 CFR 68.71)

  The Safety Manager is responsible for providing initial and refresher training to employees involved with the ammonia refrigeration system and for documenting training records for each affected employee.

Minimum training requirements include:

Initial training, with an overview of the process and the operating procedures, with an emphasis on:
(1) Specific safety and health hazards
(2) Emergency operations, including shutdown
(3) Safe work practices

Refresher training at least every 3 years

Training documentation including employee identification, training date, and means used to verify that employee understood the training


2.2.5 Mechanical Integrity  (40 CFR 68.73)

The Plant Manager is responsible for establishing and implementing written procedures to maintain the on-going integrity of the process equipment.  

Responsibilities include:
a. Establishing written maintenance procedures for the ammonia refrigeration system 
b. Inspection and testing schedules for the receivers, accumulators, pumps, piping systems, and emergency control devices
c. Training for process maintenance activities
d. Correcting equipment deficiencies
e. Assuring quality of equipment in new plants and in new equipment

 2.2.6 Management of Change (40 CFR 68.75)

The Safety Manager is responsible for:
a.  Establishing and maintaining written procedures for managing changes (in equipment, procedures, or nearby sources) to the ammonia refrigeration system that could affect process safety information, operating procedures, etc.
b. Updating other 112(r) program elements that are potentially affected by the change and ensure that affected employees have knowledge of, and are trained in, the changes to the ammonia refrigeration system.

 2.2.7 Pre-Startup Review (40 CFR 68.77)

The Plant Manager is responsible for:
 a. Performing a start-up review when a new or modified source affects the process  safety information for the ammonia refrigeration system
 b. Informing the Safety Manager of the proposed modification

 The review shall confirm that:
construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications.
safety and emergency procedures are in place.
training of each employee has occurred.
for new stationary sources, a process hazard analysis has been performed.

 The Safety Manger will ensure that affected employees are trained in working with the new or modified source.

 2.2.8 Compliance Audits (40 CFR 68.79)

The Safety Manager is responsible for assembling an auditing team to perform compliance audits at least every 3 years to ensure that the procedures and practices are adequate and being followed.  Responsibilities include ensuring that: 
 a. An audit report is prepared
 b. Audit deficiencies are corrected
 c. The two most recent audit reports are kept on file

 
2.2.9 Incident Investigation (40 CFR 68.81)

The Safety Manager is responsible for assembling a team to investigate incidents that resulted in, or could have resulted in, a release of ammonia from the ammonia refrigeration system, within 48 hours of the incident.  In addition, the Safety Manager will ensure that: 
 a. a written incident report is prepared (including date of incident, date investigation  began, description of the incident, factors contributing to the incident, and  recommendations).
 b. every potentially affected employee or contractor reviews the report.
 c. a system is established to address and resolve the report findings.
 d. the report is retained for five years.

 2.2.10 Employee Participation (40 CFR 68.83)

The Safety Manager will ensure that affected employees and contractors are consulted in development of the process hazard analysis and that all information regarding the 112(r) program is accessible to these personnel.

 2.2.11 Hot Work Permit (40 CFR 68.85)

The Plant Engineer is responsible for issuing hot work permits when hot work operations are performed on or near the ammonia refrigeration system.  The permit shall document that fire prevention and protection have been implemented prior to beginning hot work operations.  The permit shall be kept on file until after completion of the hot work.

 2.2.12 Contractors (40 CFR 68.87)

The Safety Manager is responsible for:
a. Providing contractors (that work on, or adjacent to, the ammonia refrigeration system) with information regarding the hazards of the system, emergency response actions, and any other applicable portion of the program, prior to commencement of work.
b.   Developing and implementing safe work practices in covered process areas.
c.   Periodically evaluating the performance of the contractor.

The Plant Engineer shall ensure that all proposals and contracts for work to be performed on, or adjacent to, the ammonia refrigeration system, include information on the contractor's safety performance and programs and relay that information to the Safety Manager for evaluation.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Background Data

In accordance with Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations Chapter 68 (40 CFR 68) promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Purity Dairies, Inc. (Purity Dairy) submits this Risk Management Plan (RMP) for operations at its Nashville, TN facility.  

Purity's operations include storing frozen foods, dairy products, and distribution.  Purity has been in operation at this facility for over 40 years, providing quality dairy products and over 500 jobs to the local community.


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy

In this facility, we use Anhydrous Ammonia, which is considered hazardous by the EPA.  This chemical must be used to provide cooling for the process and surrounding areas.  It is our policy to have programs in place dealing with safety precautions for handling these substances and to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to our own health, as well as to reduce the threat to nearby members of the community.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and state rules and regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle ammonia, combined with the safety devices inherent in the design of this facility, as well as the safe handling procedures that we use and the training of our personnel.

Purity Dairy is committed to protecting the health of its employees, the surrounding community, and the environment; therefore, it is Purity Dairy?s policy to maintain compliance with 40 CFR 68 as well as Occupational Safety and Health Organization (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations promulgated as Title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations Chapter 1910, Section 119 (29 CFR 1910.119), and OSHA?s Hazardous Operations and Emergency Response regulations (29 CFR 1910.120). 

Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances

Purity Dairy  is subject to 112(r) because ammonia, a regulated substance, is present at the facility in amounts greater than 10,000

pounds.  Purity Dairy is required to maintain low temperatures, which are within standards required by the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA), in the food processing areas of the plant. Purity Dairy uses anhydrous ammonia (the 112(r) regulated substance) as a refrigerant to maintain the process and facility within the required range of operating temperatures. Purity?s refrigeration system, consisting of receivers, compressors, evaporators, condensers, and piping in two systems contains a maximum amount of 38,637 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  The largest of the two systems contains 22,420 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.



Accidental Release Prevention Program

The ammonia refrigeration system is designed and constructed in accordance with ANSI/IIAR 2-1992 Standard for Equipment, Design, and Installation of Ammonia Mechanical Refrigerating Systems.  To prevent and mitigate accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia, Purity has implemented several precautionary measures.  

Purity has implemented OSHA?s PSM program and as such, has evaluated and engineered against anhydrous ammonia releases.  Some of the controls installed to prevent catastrophic releases of ammonia are: process equipment (vents, pressure relief valves, backup pumps, and manual shutoffs) and automated controls (automatic shut-offs, and electrical distribution system grounding).  In addition, Nashville Fire Department HazMat team responds to any ammonia release at the facility.  Eleven (11) Purity personnel are trained to respond to potential ammonia releases (HazMat).

Purity has developed standard operating procedures, which incorporate safety measures into the procedures, for all employees and contractors who have contact with the ammonia refrigeration system.  These safety procedures were developed by Piedmont Corporation and are reviewed on an annual basis.  Purity encourages employee participation in development of the control measures used at the plant by means of company newsletters and

training sessions.  Any changes to the operating procedures are communicated to affected employees by following written management of change procedures established by Purity.

Purity understands that maintaining the refrigeration system in good working order is essential to preventing accidental releases; therefore, Purity has implemented a preventative maintenance program.  The preventative maintenance program is scheduled, documented and managed using computer maintenance management and manual checklists with the MP2 Manager (currently Richard Dutton) to ensure that regular maintenance occurs on the system

To ensure that Purity's control measures are effective in maintaining the safe operation of the plant, regularly scheduled audits are performed on the ammonia refrigeration system:

In accordance with the PSM program, Purity conducts detailed PSM compliance audits every three years that incorporate review of process safety information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, training programs, system mechanical integrity, management of change, pre-start up review procedures, compliance audit procedures, incident investigation procedures, employee participation programs, hot work permit procedures, and contractor safety procedures. 

In addition, Purity is audited by the AIB on an annual basis.

Purity?s insurance carrier also conducts independent audits on an annual basis.


Five-Year Accident History

Over the last five years, Purity has not experienced an accidental off-site release of anhydrous ammonia from the ammonia refrigeration system

Emergency Response Program 

Purity has documented emergency response procedures in a document entitled PURITY DAIRIES EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN, to facilitate response efforts in the event of an off-site anhydrous ammonia release.  Included in the SOP are measures to be taken internally by Purity.

Purity has trained 11 on-site personnel to respond to accidental ammonia releases.  Dean Foods provided the last train

ing session on October 15, 2003 for the following personnel:

Philip Avirt
Doug Baltz
Brian Cochrane
Doug Coleman
Richard Dutton
Daniel Gregory
Ken Johnson
Kevin Pointer
Jeff Underwood
Guy Wideman
Chad.Wilson             
These personnel are trained in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.120, OSHA?s Hazardous Operations and Emergency Response regulations according to their duties and function.  These personnel received initial training and an annual update training thereafter.  As an additional training exercise, simulations of an emergency release with off-site effects are conducted regularly with the entire emergency response system. This simulation will be critiqued and changes made to the SOP as appropriate.  Purity intends to do another simulation in the near future. 

To plan for an ammonia release with off-site effects, Purity?s SOP includes procedures/equipment to mitigate the release, procedures to inform local response agencies, transportation maps for response agencies, evacuation route maps, and procedures for public communication.

In addition to the above local response agencies, Purity has available emergency response assistance from local clean-up contractors. In the event of an anhydrous ammonia release with off-site effects, the general public will be warned using the following methods:
Sirens
Broadcast message local radio stations.                  
Police and fire vehicles equipped with public address systems, and
Door-to-door notification of residents (if time permits).




Planned Changes to Improve Safety

As a result of Purity?s initial process hazard analyses, several changes are planned at the facility to improve safety and prevent anhydrous ammonia releases.  These changes are scheduled to be implemented by December 2003 and include improvements to operating procedures,  increased protection of ammonia equipment (e.g., guarding), and an ammonia leak detection system.
